name: sfchronicle
text:
Children at a home in Vallejo chant "Black Lives Matter!" as hundreds of people march and protest along Marin Street demanding justice for people killed by police officers. 

The march will end at City Hall for a candlelight vigil. 

For updates: https://t.co/DFInOj3fAa https://t.co/McmR9OwcNF

name: sfchronicle
text:
A commenter at the transit agency's board meeting decried BART police as murderers, recalling Oscar Grant.

That rankled Director Debora Allen, who called the statements ‚Äúoutrageous and false,‚Äù and accused the callers of being politically motivated.

https://t.co/j1P5lTZllB

name: sfchronicle
text:
Northern California is primed for a dangerous fire season as it emerges from a warm spring preceded by a winter with well below normal amounts of rain and snow. 

The situation poses a big test for PG&E. https://t.co/yeHpKGek2Z

name: sfchronicle
text: JUST IN: Fort Bragg will consider letting voters decide whether to change the city's name amid national calls for names and statues honoring the Confederacy to be removed. https://t.co/NypNBlbpXh

name: sfchronicle
text: Calls for change are sweeping the sports world, from college campuses, to hockey rinks and NASCAR racetracks and even into the basement of NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell. The sports world is engaged. https://t.co/DCRGQP9YzT

name: sfchronicle
text:
UCSF plans to knock down UC Hall, where 10 New Deal frescoes are located, as part of an ambitious plan to build a new hospital and research campus. However, it doesn't have the $8 million it would cost to move the artwork to a new building. 
https://t.co/880BDJIcfE

text: Megayachts, cheap shots & bon mots ‚Å†‚Äî read @ScottOstler's latest sports thoughts.  https://t.co/PvuU8IeDuv

name: sfchronicle
text:
A recent viral Twitter video shows two people accusing a man of defacing private property for drawing Black Lives Matter on what he says is his own home in San Francisco's Pacific Heights.

https://t.co/JYmLo0PDNP

name: sfchronicle
text:
In the wake of COVID-19 and financial challenges, UCSF decides not to use public funds to preserve 10 New Deal-era murals currently on the UCSF Parnassus campus. Up to $8 million is needed to safely move and preserve the murals, or they will be destroyed.
https://t.co/m7HnDsaPm2

name: sfchronicle
text: The #GrantFire in Sacramento County burned 5,042 and was 65% contained today. Follow The Chronicle's Fire Tracker for more details: https://t.co/YdmjIXnIsX https://t.co/VWhq6E8xp2

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
Napa County, which has had by far the lowest case count in the Bay Area, recorded 15 new cases on Saturday ‚Äî its highest number to date.

More than one-fifth of the county's total case count has come in the past week. https://t.co/i2REDYMzIN

name: sfchronicle
text: The SF police narcotics unit has been very busy since its return to the streets. The rebooted unit, along with Tenderloin beat cops, arrested 69 suspected street dealers from May 18 to June 5 ‚Äî that‚Äôs nearly four a day. https://t.co/RbrdD29Ml4

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/Trr8wV61qR

name: sfchronicle
text:
Are you ready to get a haircut? How about going to a local museum, staying at a hotel, or going wine tasting? 

Take our poll here (we've even ranked the risk of the activities according to virus experts): https://t.co/uhIB9Xel1K

name: sfchronicle
text:
How safe is staying at a hotel? 
Or going out for dinner and a drink?
Or getting a haircut at a salon?
The Chronicle asked infectious disease experts to rate the risk of some popular activities based on a scale of 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk). https://t.co/gJrvEDPKrM

name: sfchronicle
text:
For the first time since March, a Bay Area film festival is set to have a live event.

@framelinefest will host a screening of the world premiere of @CurveMagMovie at the West Wind Solano Drive-In Theater in Concord, on June 27. https://t.co/aLKz138COl

name: sfchronicle
text: Bay Area physicians are ramping up their practices, resuming surgeries, preventive care and procedures like colonoscopies, but the COVID-19 pandemic has changed the way doctoring is done and many physicians in small offices are struggling. https://t.co/umi2FITLD2

name: sfchronicle
text:
Federal prisons across the country have seen 82 inmate deaths from COVID-19 and the death of one staff member, the Bureau of Prisons reported.
https://t.co/pEZz1eIooK

name: sfchronicle
text:
At least seven officers on the Minneapolis force have quit and another seven are in the process of resigning.

They cited a lack of support from department and city leaders as protests over George Floyd‚Äôs killing escalated.
https://t.co/HK6SFMupVa

name: sfchronicle
text:
How accurate are the coronavirus tests used in the U.S.?

Months into the outbreak, no one really knows how well many of the screening tests work, the Associated Press reports.
https://t.co/2AnW6lMkPX
